questions.question_text:
Your database is running in ARCHIVELOG mode. You use RMAN to take image copies and you update these copies incrementally every six hours. After a regular maintenance task, when you attempt to restart the instance, it halts in MOUNT state with an error indicating that one of the data files belonging to the EXAMPLE tablespace is lost.
You want to recover the data file as quickly as possible while maximizing availability for the database.
Examine the possible steps involved in the recovery process:
1. Mount the database.
2. Take the data file offline.
3. Bring the tablespace online.
4. Use the RMAN SWITCH command to switch to the image copy.
5. Recover the tablespace.
6. Open the database.
7. Use the RMAN RESTORE command to switch to the image copy.
Identify the correct sequence of the required steps.

discussion.content: Can we take a datafile offline if the database is not in mount mode? A and B options do not mount the database. I am confused.

comments.content: Sorry, I just re-read the question and it states the database halts in mount.

discussion.content: A is correct instead of B because to maximize availability for the database
B is correct. remember, OPEN database is the last step you would do after you have recovered the data files.

comments.content: after open the database, you can online tablespace .
Answer A. If database is in mount status, there is no need to take datafile offline for restoring&recovering datafile, and just need to switch to copy, recover datafile, then open database.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about RMAN duplexed backups?

choices.B: All historical data older than two years, if any, is purged from the flashback archive FDA1.
choices.D: All historical data older than two years, if any, is archived to flashback logs and the flashback archive is set to new retention time.
choices.C: All the flashback data archives are purged and the subsequently created flashback archives are maintained for two years.
choices.A: An error is returned because the retention period cannot be reduced.

questions.question_text:
You enable Flashback Data Archive for a table for which you want to track and save all transactions for four years. After some time, the requirement changes for keeping transactions from four to two years.
You execute the following command to change the requirement:
SQL> ALTER flashback archive fda1 MODIFY RETENSION 2 YEAR;
What is the outcome?

comments.content: D. All historical data older than two years, if any, is archived to flashback logs and the flashback archive is set to new retention time.

discussion.content: Flashback data archives retain historical data for the time duration specified using the RETENTION parameter. Historical data can be queried using the Flashback Query AS OF clause. Archived historic data that has aged beyond the specified retention period is automatically purged.

I would go for B.
I could not find any evidence for D in the docs...

comments.content:
I agree with you, it does not purge data files.
REF: http://www.dba-oracle.com/t_rman_162_modify_flashback_archive.htm

D is the correct based on FDA feature.
It means that you can use any flashback query which contains two years of historical information regarding the table that is assigned to this flashback archive.
it does NOT purge data files though
